# General context

## Livestock's part in the global food security challenge

- Food demand is expected to increase between **30%** and **62%** by 2050 [@vandijkMetaanalysisProjectedGlobal2021].
- Failure of the Green Revolution to address global food security [@cassidyRedefiningAgriculturalYields2013; @garibaldiFarmingApproachesGreater2017].
- Globalised grain-feed systems:
  - decline and degradation of global grassland areas [@bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021];
  - large environmental externalities [@cunninghamCloseYieldgapSaving2013; @hongGlobalRegionalDrivers2021].

## {.center}

![Extent of degraded grasslands worldwide, from @bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021.](illustrations/presentation/bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021.png){#fig-bardgett}

## Beyond the productivist perspective

**Agricultural multifunctionality**: synergy between food security, the integrity of ecosystems and human well-being [@fischerReframingFoodBiodiversity2017; @ipbesThematicAssessmentReport2024].

:::{.notes}
- **Ecosystem services**: ecological characteristics, functions or processes used for the economic valuation of ecosystem contributions to human well-being [@costanzaTwentyYearsEcosystem2017; @haines-youngCommonInternationalClassification2018].
- **Multifunctionality**: capacity of agricultural systems to ensure the delivery of multiple ecosystem services [@oecdMultifunctionalityAnalyticalFramework2001].
:::

![Ecosystem service trade-offs with land management, from @kremenLandscapesThatWork2018.](illustrations/presentation/kremenLandscapesThatWork2018A.png){#fig-kremen width="90%" style="margin:20px"}

## Biodiversity x ecosystem services

![Positive relationship between the range of ecosystem processes and species richness, from @hectorBiodiversityEcosystemMultifunctionality2007.](illustrations/presentation/hectorBiodiversityEcosystemMultifunctionality2007.webp){#fig-hector}

:::{.notes}
- how biodiversity relates to these bundles ?
- Expected synergies: underlying ecosystem processes affected by different sets of species [@hectorBiodiversityEcosystemMultifunctionality2007; @soliveresBiodiversityMultipleTrophic2016].
:::

## Synergies and trade-offs {.center}

![The multiple drivers of cultural, aboveground regulating and provisioning ecosystem services in grasslands, from @leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022.](illustrations/presentation/leprovostAdapted.png){#fig-leprovost}

:::{.notes}
- Highly context-dependent in relation to the local environment and the type of management
- If the aim is to favour practices that support biodiversity and maximise synergies without too much trade-offs for productivity
- then we need policy-oriented research to investigate synergies and trade-offs under different farming models and across multiple ecosystems and sociocultural backgrounds [@egliWinnersLosersNational2018; @rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017].
:::

# Ecological study in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve

## Aim of the thesis

- This PhD thesis aims to **explore how grazing-dependent habitats support biodiversity and ecosystem service delivery** in the agroecological landscape of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
<!-- - Our work was based on observational studies of **42 semi-natural grasslands and heathlands**, distributed across a west-east gradient in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. -->

## Papers

- **Paper I**: effect of rotational prescribed burning on beetle diversity and ecological preferences.
- **Paper II**: influence of livestock type (sheep, cattle, goat) and landscape zone (coastal, fjord) on plant diversity and forage and pollination services in semi-natural grasslands.
- **Paper III**: cross-scale interactions between environmental and management factors of semi-natural grasslands, and their influences on dominant grass, forb and dung-associated beetle assemblages.
- **Paper IV**: trade-offs and synergies between ecosystem service indicators across different field types (infield, outfield) and landscape zones (coastal, fjord, mountain).

## Main questions

- **(Q1)** What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?
  - **(Q1-1)** What are the productivity patterns along the coast-to-mountain gradient (**paper IV**)?
  - **(Q1-2)** Can we detect the influence of geographic or climatic factors on the taxonomic and functional composition of semi-natural grasslands (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?

## Main questions

- **(Q1)** What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?
- **(Q2)** How does management influence the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (**paper I**, **paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?
  - **(Q2-1)** Is there an effect of livestock type on the diversity and community composition in semi-natural grasslands (**paper II**, **paper III**)?
  - **(Q2-2)** What is the effect of prescribed burning on taxonomic and functional diversity in semi-natural heathlands (**paper I**, **paper IV**)?
  
## Main questions

- **(Q1)** What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?

## Study approach {.smaller}

+--------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+
| Indicators               | Ecosystem services              | Sensitivity                     | Papers                          |
+:=========================+:================================+:================================+=================================+
| grass                    | forage production               |                                 | paper II, paper III, paper IV   |
+--------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+
| forbs                    | pollination, forage production  | livestock selectivity           | paper II, paper III, paper IV   |
+--------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+
| cryptogams               | water retention                 | fertilisation, trampling        | paper IV                        |
+--------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+
+--------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+
| beetles                  | NA                              | vegetation structure            | paper I                         |
+--------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+
| dung-associated beetles  | nutrient cycling                | dung availability               | paper III                       |
+--------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+
| soil mesofauna           | nutrient cycling                | fertilisation                   | paper IV                        |
+--------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+---------------------------------+

::: {.notes}
- We relied on multiple taxonomic and functional indicators to obtain a comprehensive assessment of the impact of management on the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands.
- The analyses of functional groups and traits, which directly express species' responses to abiotic stress and disturbance [@mouillotFunctionalApproachReveals2013], are particularly pertinent in our study context.
:::

## Postfire response {visibility="hidden"}

- Building from previous studies from @bargmannEffectsPrescribedBurning2015 and @bargmannSpeciesTraitSelection2016, who investigated postfire response of Carabidae in Western Norway.
- Investigation families with high specialisation level (e.g. Staphylinidae) and functional traits

## Farm management

- Farmer interviews: 39 interviews between October 2021 and January 2022, successively led by Linn Voldstad and Silje Östman.
- Information on management practices:
  - the livestock breed;
  - the number of adult and young animals (**paper III**);
  - the surface area of the field we visited (**paper III**);
  - the occupation period of the field by livestock (**paper III**);
  - the grazing history including current and former livestock as well as past land use;
  - the type, frequency and intensity of additional management, e.g. fertilisation, mulching and burning.

## Analytical methods {.smaller}

+------------+------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------+
| Papers     | Response                                       | Explanatory                                 | Analyses                                              |
+:===========+:===============================================+:============================================+:======================================================+
| paper I    | diversity, community, ecological preferences   | pioneer vs mature heath                     | Wilcoxon, CCA (ordination), indicator (IndVal, phi)   |
+------------+------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------+
| paper II   | diversity, community, ES indicators            | livestock type, landscape zone              | LMM, Kendall, Pearson, Spearman, MCDP                 |
+------------+------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------+
| paper III  | community                                      | scales (regional, landscape, field, fine)   | CCA (canonical correlation), RDA                      |
+------------+------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------+
| paper IV   | diversity, biomass, abundance                  | field type, geographical location           | HAC, Spearman, effect size                            |
+------------+------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------+

## Result summary

- **(Q1)** What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?
  - Range-dependent: hump-shaped productivity pattern at larger scale, but no evidence of independent influence within the higher productivity range.
- **(Q2)** How does management influence the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?
- **(Q3)** What are the synergies and trade-offs between indicators of biodiversity and ecosystem services among semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?

## Result summary

- **(Q1)** What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?
- **(Q2)** How does management influence the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?
  - Grazing: cattle-grazed fields associated with higher Poaceae cover, but no clear evidence of direct or indirect effect on diversity or the composition of dominant plant, forb and dung-associated beetle assemblages;
  - Prescribed burning: lower alpha diversity after fire, divergence in community composition between pioneer and mature patches driven by ecological preferences.
- **(Q3)** What are the synergies and trade-offs between indicators of biodiversity and ecosystem services among semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?

## Result summary

- **(Q1)** What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?
- **(Q2)** How does management influence the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?
- **(Q3)** What are the synergies and trade-offs between indicators of biodiversity and ecosystem services among semi-natural grasslands and heathlands?
  - Semi-natural heathlands: higher plant diversity and soil carbon content;
  - Semi-natural grasslands: higher forb biomass, no tradeoff between vascular plant diversity and forage resource.

# Methodological considerations

## Complex interactions in small-scale grazing systems

:::{.notes}
Our findings suggested that the independent influences of the environmental gradients and field management on the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands were mediated by their mutual interactions at different spatial scales (**paper II**, **paper III**).
The inconsistent outcomes from **paper III** may also suggest that relationships between the underlying regional gradient and plant and dung-associated beetle communities are characterised by more complex interactions [@dixonhamilCrossscaleContradictionsEcological2016; @petersCrossScaleInteractions2007] (see Discussion in **paper III**).
In **paper II** for example, we observed significant changes in plant functional group cover due to interactions between landscape zone and livestock type:
coastal sites grazed by cattle were characterised by the lowest forb cover, while fjord sites grazed by cattle showed the lowest grass/forb cover ratio.
On the other hand, we observed that dominant grass and forb assemblages were consistently correlated with a gradient of vegetation structure, which itself showed a weak correlation with the field management (**paper III**).
:::

## Limitations of our study design {visibility="hidden"}

- the scale, whether for capturing environmental heterogeneity (e.g. fjord topography) or management-driven heterogeneity (e.g. rotational management)
- the biological indicators: especially arthropods

:::{.notes}
- Environmental heterogeneity
- Livestock-driven heterogeneity at the field scale
- Management-driven heterogeneity at the landscape scale
- Selection of biological indicators
:::

## Optimisation methodological approach

- **Spatially-explicit analyses**, to disentangle the respective influences of management and underlying environmental gradients [e.g. @wittmanSocialEcologicalPerspective2017; @redlichDisentanglingEffectsClimate2022];
- **Farm-scale approaches**, to address environmental and management-driven variance as an inherent determinant of agroecological systems [@deffontainesAgriculturalSystemsLandscape1995; @sinclairOptionsContextApproach2019];
- **High resolution indicators**, with priority given to taxa contributing to key ecosystem functions [@bardgettBelowgroundBiodiversityEcosystem2014; @degraaffEffectsAgriculturalIntensification2019];
- **Transdisciplinary approaches**, to ensure the pertinence, applicability and accessibility of agroecological research [@bennettLinkingBiodiversityEcosystem2015; @jagerPathwaysImplementationEvidence2020].

## Perspectives for the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve

- We recommend to **deepen collaboration with local farmers** to investigate more thoroughly the plant and animal communities of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands in relation to management.
- Further research could aim for:
  <!-- - comparing the evolution of plant communities of semi-natural grasslands over time and determine whether they have been affected by the changes in management; -->
  - leading **farm-scale assessments** of plant and animal communities, for a better consideration of the management rotational dynamic;
  - addressing **Norways's knowledge gaps** regarding arthropods' response to management and environmental factors;
  - integrating biodiversity assessments within the **ecosystem service framework** in order to facilitate local and regional policy-making.

# Conclusion

## Conclusion

- Exploring farming alternatives based on agroecological principles has become a priority to support the sustainable use of land resources and preserve the integrity of ecosystems.
- This thesis aimed to contribute to this objective by using the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (Western Norway) as a case study.
- Overall, my thesis **adds to the evidence that win-win strategies promoting biodiversity and multifunctionality are already within our reach**.
- I encourage further research efforts on already existing models of small-scale and diversified farming, to understand how adaptative management strategies interact with the local context.

## The Intermediate Disturbance Hypothesis {visibility="uncounted"}

![Plant diversity of grassland communities in relation to grazing intensity along gradients of moisture and grazing evolutionary history, from @milchunasGeneralizedModelEffects1988](illustrations/presentation/milchunasGeneralizedModelEffects1988.png){#fig-milchunas}

:::{.notes}
- At moderate intensity, grazing pressure is expected to be strong enough to locally overcome the competition for light, but not so excessive as to homogenise the sward with grazing-tolerant species [@koernerChangeDominanceDetermines2018; @olffEffectsHerbivoresGrassland1998].
- This intermediate stage of highest spatial heterogeneity should result in a biodiversity optimum, by favouring the coexistence of multiple life strategies and ecological niches for plant and animal communities [@ceraboliniWhyAreMany2016; @steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014].
:::

:::{.notes}
- In nutrient-poor habitats, the prevalence of stress-tolerance strategies usually limits plant growth rate and reproductive capacities [@diazGlobalSpectrumPlant2016; @pierceLeafEconomicsSpectrum2007], increasing the vulnerability of communities to ruderal and fast-growing species [@pakemanConsistencyPlantSpecies2004; @teuberLivestockGrazingIntermountain2013].
- The relationship between grazing and biodiversity thus depends on both the ecosystem capacity to tolerate disturbance [@piipponenGlobalTrendsGrassland2022] and the management adaptability to abiotic constraints [@plieningerTraditionalLanduseNature2006; @torokGrazingEuropeanOpen2016].
:::

## The Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve {visibility="uncounted"}

- **UNESCO's Man and the Biosphere Programme (MAB)**: aims to "improve human livelihoods, and the equitable sharing of benefits, and to safeguard natural and managed ecosystems, promoting innovative approaches to economic development that are socially and culturally appropriate and environmentally sustainable" [@unescoManBiosphereProgramme2025].
- **Biosphere Reserves**: model areas for experimenting innovative pathways for sustainable development [@barracloughGlobalKnowledgeAction2023; @unescoNewRoadmapMan2017].
- World Network of Biosphere Reserves: 784 sites across 142 countries for a total population of 300 million people [@unescoManBiosphereProgramme2025].

## Agriculture history in Western Norway {visibility="uncounted"}

- Early Neolithic: introduction of burning and domestic grazing [@hjelleHesitantHuntersReview2006; @prosch-danielsenPalaeoecologicalInvestigationsReconstruction2000].
- **Traditional infield-outfield system**: mixed crop-livestock system, involving energy transfers from grazed outfields (*utmark*) to cultivated infields (*innmark*).
- Post-WW2 rationalisation: livestock moved to the infields to address market demands, leading to enlargement and intensification of fertile fields and abandonment of remote and nutrient-poor areas [@jonesLandtenureLandscapeChange1988].
- Smaller holdings (under 10 ha) most impacted: dropped from representing 90% of total Norwegian farms in 1949 to 53% in 1995 [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999].

## Current stakes {visibility="hidden"}

- Small-scale grazing systems of Western retain high ecological diversity compared with Eastern plains and of habitats threatened at European scales
- Need to develop agricultural pathways ensuring both the socioeconomic development of the countryside and the preservation of the ecological diversity.
- Deepen our understanding of the ecological dynamics under current management to assess the impact of current management practices
